required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Interstitial Fluid in the Development of Cardiovascular Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Studies of the Importance of Interstitial Fluid in the Development of Cardiovascular Disease, an Expanded Study.

brief_summary.textblock:
At a given level of serum cholesterol, patients with T2D have an increased risk of developing atherosclerosis compared with nondiabetic subjects.
In a previous study we showed that the interstitial fluid-to-serum gradient of LDL and VLDL cholesterol is reduced in T2D patients compared with healthy controls. This was not found for HDL cholesterol. However, the cholesterol transporting function of HDL particles from interstitial fluid from patients with T2D were lower than in healthy controls. We hypothesize that that the apo B-containing particles in T2D patients are more susceptible to be retained or consumed in the extravascular space.
We are to study if skin biopsies from T2D patients contain more cholesterol than biopsies from healthy controls. We hypothesize that samples from T2D patients are richer in cholesterol, which could explain why VLDL and LDL cholesterol are lower in relation to their plasma levels in T2D.

primary_outcome.measure: Interstitial fluid-to-serum ratio for LDL cholesterol

intervention.intervention_name: Collection of interstitial fluid, skin biopsies and blood
intervention.description: Collection of interstitial fluid, skin biopsies and blood

biospec_descr.textblock: Interstitial fluid, skin biopsies and blood (serum, plasma and whole blood)

study_pop.textblock: Healthy controls and type 2 diabetes patients over 18 years old, matched for age and gender.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Over 18 years.
- For the T2D study group: Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy
- Markers for thyroid disease or inflammation out of normal range.
- Self-reporting thyriod disease, inflammatory disease, kidney disease or cutaneous diseases.
- Self-reporting asthma or COPD treated with oral glucocorticoids.
Additional exclusion criteria for the healthy controls:
- Blood Pressure >140/90.
- Blood lipids or glucose out of normal range.
- Markers for liver or kidney function out of normal range.
- Self-reporting type 2 diabetes or cardiovascular disease.
- Drug treatment (excl. contraception and antihistamines).

facility.name: Patient research centre, Clinic of endocrinology, Karolinska University Hospital
